canonicalWording: Consequential damages (broad, inflationary)
definition: Liability for indirect damages like lost profits, delay of projects, lost rental income, increased financing costs, lost opportunity costs, or business interruption. Insurance may not cover these expansive damages.
suggestedAction: Do not indemnify GCs or project owners for consequential damages.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit liability for "consequential", "indirect", or "special" damages
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Liability includes lost profits, loss of use, or business interruption
confidenceRubric.weak: Silence on consequential damages (implies liability in some jurisdictions)

canonicalWording: Liquidated damages
definition: Predetermined damages paid for each day of delay. Even small delays with small claims can lead to large liquidated damages. May include act of God delays. Insurance carriers may not provide coverage.
suggestedAction: Avoid signing up for liquidated damages indemnification.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit "liquidated damages" clause with amount/rate
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Clear daily penalty for delay
confidenceRubric.weak: Mentions damages for delay without specific LD structure

canonicalWording: "Arising out of" language instead of "caused by"
definition: Broad causal link for indemnity ("arising out of") vs. narrow ("caused by"). "Arising out of" is extremely broad and can pull you into claims even when your work did not cause the damage.
suggestedAction: Replace "arising out of" with "caused by" language—indemnity should only apply to claims caused in whole or in part by your work.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Use of "arising out of" or "in connection with" regarding indemnity scope
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Broad causal language linking work to claims without direct causation

canonicalWording: Indemnifying GC for their sole or willful negligence
definition: Requirement to indemnify the GC even for their own sole or willful negligence. You should not sign up for liability that is not your fault.
suggestedAction: Avoid this. Contracts should read that the claim was caused by your work before you indemnify.
falsePositiveTraps: Indemnity to fullest extent permitted by law (often saves this)

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit requirement to indemnify for GC's "sole negligence" or "willful misconduct"
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Indemnity applies regardless of whether caused by Indemnitee
confidenceRubric.weak: Broad indemnity without sole negligence exclusion

canonicalWording: Being asked to enroll in an OCIP after work has started
definition: Requirement to enroll in an OCIP/CCIP after work has commenced. You will not have coverage for work done before enrollment, and may trigger exclusions under your own CGL policy. Must get backdated coverage in writing or decline enrollment.
suggestedAction: Always confirm eligibility with your agent before enrolling. Request the manual and contact the OCIP administrator. Allow a minimum of 5 business days to explore enrollment. Never enroll after work has started unless you get written confirmation of backdated coverage. If not eligible, do not enroll—it may trigger exclusions under your own CGL policy.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit requirement to enroll in OCIP/CCIP despite work having started
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Clause stating insurance program enrollment is required at any stage

canonicalWording: Required completed operations additional insured
definition: Requirement to name additional insureds for completed operations coverage. Crane companies are service providers, not contractors - when the hoist is done, your work is done. Completed ops AI allows GCs to pull you into claims years later for work you are not responsible for.
suggestedAction: Do not provide completed operations additional insured endorsements. Remove this from all contracts. Push back on every certificate request.
falsePositiveTraps: General AI requirement without completed ops

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit requirement for "completed operations" additional insured status
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Requirement to maintain AI status after project completion
confidenceRubric.weak: General additional insured clause without completed ops mention

canonicalWording: Indemnity against acts of god
definition: Requirement to indemnify for events outside human control (acts of God). It is outside your control whether there is an act of God that prevents you from doing your work. Includes site conditions unsuitable for work due to soil compaction, water flow, etc.
suggestedAction: Remove indemnification for acts of God from contracts. Do not sign up for liquidated damages that can be caused in whole or in part by acts of God.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit indemnity for "acts of God" or natural disasters
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Indemnity regardless of cause or fault, including nature
confidenceRubric.weak: Broad indemnity without specific act of God inclusion

canonicalWording: Indemnifying for underground conditions or site survey
definition: Indemnity for damage to underground utilities or unknown site conditions. A third party should do site survey and locate underground. GC/owner should agree (not dictate) equipment placement. Do not indemnify for damage to underground utilities.
suggestedAction: Do not indemnify for damage to underground utilities or site conditions.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit indemnity for underground/subsurface conditions or utilities
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor assumes all risk of site conditions

canonicalWording: Unseen master contract pass-through provisions
definition: Incorporation of a Prime/Master Contract that is not attached. Multiple contracts (bid, PO, tags, master agreement) may dictate liability. Understand which contract has precedence.
suggestedAction: Request a copy of the master contract before signing. Understand which contract has precedence and review all incorporated documents.

confidenceRubric.explicit: States Master Agreement is incorporated/governs
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor bound to Contractor as Contractor is to Owner
confidenceRubric.weak: Reference to Prime Contract without full incorporation

searchQueries: bound to contractor as contractor bound to owner

canonicalWording: Poor, drawn-out payment terms (Pay-if-Paid)
definition: Unfavorable payment schedules (e.g., Pay-if-Paid, long delays). Pay-if-Paid makes owner payment a condition precedent to your payment.
suggestedAction: Negotiate for 'pay-when-paid' instead of 'pay-if-paid.' Avoid payment terms exceeding 60 days. Negotiate reasonable retainage terms and timely release.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit "Pay-if-Paid" or payment terms > 60 days
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Payment contingent on Owner payment as condition precedent

canonicalWording: Bailment - responsibility for third-party property
definition: Liability for property of others while in your care/custody. Bailment coverage spans warehouse storage, cargo/transit, job site, and during rigging/hoist. May need coverage on multiple policies (CGL care-custody-control, riggers liability, cargo/inland marine). Limit liability in bids/tags if property value is not declared.
suggestedAction: Clearly identify in contracts, bids, purchase orders, and tags how much bailment coverage you'll provide (or if you'll provide any). Make this a discussion point so there are no surprises. Review care, custody, control endorsements with your agent.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit assumption of liability for third-party property/cargo
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Responsibility for goods in transit, storage, or during rigging

canonicalWording: Indemnity for others' tools and equipment
definition: Requirement to indemnify for tools/equipment belonging to others. Every contractor should be responsible for their own tools and equipment, even if you are hoisting them.
suggestedAction: Do not indemnify anyone for their tools and equipment. Every contractor should be responsible for their own.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Indemnity covers use of Contractor's or others' equipment
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor liable for any equipment on site

canonicalWording: Indemnity for crane access and site security
definition: Indemnity for site access routes or security of the crane. Large claims have been caused by unauthorized people near crane equipment. Site security and access control should be spelled out - GC should be responsible.
suggestedAction: Do not sign up to be responsible for site security. Ensure the subcontract spells out that the GC/owner is responsible for site security and limiting access to the crane. Consider adding this to your bids or tickets.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Indemnity for site access accidents or security failures
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor assumes risk of site access conditions and security

canonicalWording: Joint ventures, bare rentals, borrowed servant
definition: Clauses creating joint liability, joint employment, or borrowed servant status. When renting equipment without operator to another crane company, they must be responsible for the crane value, and provide AI status and waivers of subrogation on GL, excess, auto, and workers comp.
suggestedAction: Ensure liability and indemnity are clearly delineated. If bare-renting equipment, require the renter to be responsible for the crane's value, provide you additional insured on their GL and excess, and provide waivers of subrogation on GL, excess, auto, and workers comp.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit "borrowed servant" or "joint venture" language
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Employees deemed employees of Contractor

canonicalWording: Certificates required past project completion (statute of repose)
definition: Requirement to maintain insurance/certificates for years after completion (e.g., 10 years for CA SB-800). Crane entities are service providers, not contractors - should not be subject to construction defect timelines. Remove certificate holders when project completes.
suggestedAction: Reject contracts requiring a multi-year certificate tail. Do not provide certificates past project completion. When you renew, remove those certificate holders.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Requirement to maintain insurance for statute of repose/limitations or >2 years after completion
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Extended completed operations coverage required for multiple years

canonicalWording: Making architects or engineers additional insured
definition: Requirement to name design professionals (Architects/Engineers) as AI. There is no merit to this request - these parties typically do not reciprocate AI and could not be causality to your claims.
suggestedAction: Do not provide additional insured endorsements to architects or engineers.
falsePositiveTraps: Design-build where you have design responsibility

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit requirement to add Architect/Engineer as Additional Insured
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: AI status extends to all agents/consultants/design professionals of Owner

canonicalWording: Traffic control indemnification (if not providing)
definition: Indemnity for traffic control operations when you are not providing the traffic control services. If you do provide traffic control, recommend separating that entity from crane/rigging to compartmentalize liability.
suggestedAction: Do not indemnify for traffic control unless you're providing those services. If you do provide traffic control, consider wholly separating that entity from your crane/heavy haul operation to compartmentalize liability.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Indemnity covers traffic control or MOT operations
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Responsibility for public way safety/traffic

canonicalWording: Additional insured in favor of homeowners
definition: Requirement to name individual homeowners or HOAs as Additional Insured. Never make a homeowner an additional insured, especially with completed operations. Homeowners can be difficult - deal with issues directly rather than through insurance.
suggestedAction: Never make a homeowner an additional insured, especially with completed operations. Deal with minor issues directly rather than giving them access to your GL policy.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Requirement to name Homeowners or HOA as Additional Insured
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: AI extends to residential unit owners
confidenceRubric.weak: Owner defined broadly to potentially include residents

canonicalWording: Scope must be limited to crane service when others are rigging
definition: When you are only providing crane service and others are rigging, scope of work and indemnity must be limited to crane service only. The rigger should indemnify the crane company.
suggestedAction: Ensure your contract limits indemnity to your actual scope (crane service only). The rigger should indemnify the crane company when you're only providing crane service.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Scope includes rigging by others or vague "hoisting services"
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor responsible for all rigging even when not performing it

canonicalWording: Being asked to sign a contract after work is completed
definition: Requirement to sign the agreement after services have already been rendered
suggestedAction: Do not sign contracts after work has been completed. Negotiate and sign all contracts before work begins. If pressured to sign retroactively, consult your attorney.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Explicit statement that contract applies retroactively to completed work
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Clause acknowledging work done prior to signature

canonicalWording: GC's Warranty or Guarantee beyond standard workmanship
definition: Broad warranty or guarantee obligations beyond standard workmanship. Crane companies are service providers - warranty should be limited to proper operation of equipment.
suggestedAction: Limit warranty to proper operation of equipment only. Crane companies are service providers—do not warrant construction outcomes or results.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Broad warranty/guarantee of results or performance beyond standard workmanship
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Clause guaranteeing satisfaction or specific outcomes

canonicalWording: "Subcontractor" should be "Service Provider"
definition: Crane companies are service providers, not subcontractors. Being called "Subcontractor" subjects you to construction contract obligations that may not apply to service providers.
suggestedAction: Request that 'Subcontractor' be changed to 'Service Provider' or 'Vendor' to avoid construction-specific obligations that don't apply to crane service.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Agreement refers to party as "Subcontractor"
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Agreement is titled "Subcontract Agreement"

canonicalWording: Insurance limits should match project size
definition: Liability limits should match project profitability. For contracts under $15-25K, provide only base GL ($1M/$2M). $25K-$125K add first excess layer. $125K-$250K add more. Only provide full tower ($15-35M+) for large, long-term projects.
suggestedAction: Match limits to project size. Provide only your first layer of GL ($1M/$2M) for contracts under $15–25K. Add excess layers proportionally as contract value increases. Push back when small projects demand excessive limits.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Requires Umbrella/Excess limits significantly exceeding project value
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: High limit requirements for small contract value

canonicalWording: Mediation vs. arbitration dispute resolution
definition: Understand the difference between mediation and arbitration for claim settlement. Consult your attorney about which is preferable for your situation.
suggestedAction: Consult your attorney about whether mediation or arbitration is preferable for your situation before agreeing to binding dispute resolution terms.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Binding arbitration clause
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Disputes resolved by AAA rules

canonicalWording: Competent person commitments exceeding OSHA
definition: Requirements for "competent person" beyond standard OSHA definitions. Do not agree to provide competent person for other parties or indemnify for site safety of other subcontractors.
suggestedAction: Avoid providing your competent person for others or indemnifying for this. Do not sign up for responsibility for other parties' site safety.
falsePositiveTraps: Site safety rep for your crew only

confidenceRubric.explicit: Competent person required for other parties or on site at all times
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Responsible for site safety of other subcontractors

canonicalWording: Conflicts between bid/PO terms and contract
definition: Clause stating contract supersedes all prior proposals/bids. Multiple documents (bid, PO, tags, master agreement) may dictate liability - understand which has precedence.
suggestedAction: Work with an attorney to review all documents and understand which contract takes precedence. Ensure your bid terms and limitations of liability are clear.
falsePositiveTraps: Clear order of precedence favorable to you

confidenceRubric.explicit: Contract supersedes all prior negotiations and proposals
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Integration clause excluding your bid terms
confidenceRubric.weak: Documents listed in order of precedence

canonicalWording: Indemnity for damage to sidewalks, roads, curbs
definition: Liability for damage to site surroundings/infrastructure from heavy equipment. Third party should analyze and locate utilities. Do not indemnify GC/owner for this - may get pulled in when not at fault.
suggestedAction: Do not indemnify GCs, owners, or other subs for this. Have a third party analyze and locate utilities. Avoid blanket indemnification that pulls you in when you're not at fault.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Subcontractor liable for all damage to approaches, sidewalks, roads
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Repair of all damage caused by equipment access regardless of fault

canonicalWording: Crane co-work: setup/takedown or multiple crane companies
definition: When multiple crane companies work together (setup/takedown, crane assist), liability must be clearly delineated. Who indemnifies whom? Both should not indemnify the GC with arising-out-of language.
suggestedAction: Ensure liability and indemnity are clearly delineated between crane companies. Both parties should not indemnify the GC with arising-out-of language.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Multiple crane operations without clear liability separation
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Both crane parties indemnifying GC broadly

canonicalWording: Work near/over water requiring USL&H coverage
definition: Work near or over bodies of water creates USL&H exposure on workers compensation. Need USL&H coverage for drowning and maritime exposures. Some inland marine policies exclude over-water claims.
suggestedAction: Get USL&H insurance on your workers comp for drowning coverage. Consult your agent for additional coverage concerns.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Work specifically over or adjacent to navigable water
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Waterfront, pier, dock, or maritime work

canonicalWording: Railroad work requiring special coverage
definition: Work on, over, or adjacent to railroad requires railroad protective insurance. Special endorsements available on GL. Required for lifting/moving railroad cars or crossing rail lines.
suggestedAction: Be aware of railroad protective insurance requirements and endorsements available on your GL.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Work directly on or over active railroad
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Railroad protective insurance required

canonicalWording: Equipment being helicoptered in
definition: Equipment being helicoptered in may be excluded from inland marine policies. Special aviation coverage may be needed. Verify coverage before accepting project.
suggestedAction: Verify aviation coverage with your agent before accepting the project. Your inland marine policy may exclude helicopter operations.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Equipment specifically transported by helicopter
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Aerial lift or helicopter operations required

canonicalWording: Waiver of subrogation on WC, GL, Auto
definition: Requirement to waive subrogation rights. Important when bare renting equipment - need waiver from party renting your equipment on GL, excess, auto, and workers comp.
suggestedAction: When bare renting equipment, require waiver of subrogation from the renter on GL, excess, auto, and workers comp. Confirm your policy permits waivers.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Mandatory waiver of subrogation required
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Insurer must waive rights against Contractor

canonicalWording: Primary non-contributory on GL/Auto
definition: Insurance must be primary and non-contributory - your insurance pays first without contribution from others.
suggestedAction: Confirm your policy supports primary and non-contributory endorsements. This is a standard request—verify with your agent that your policy can accommodate it.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Required to be Primary and Non-Contributory
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Your insurance responds first and alone

canonicalWording: Ongoing operations additional insured
definition: Requirement for AI status for ongoing operations. This is generally acceptable unlike completed operations AI.
suggestedAction: This is generally acceptable. Verify your policy supports ongoing operations AI endorsements (CG 20 10 or equivalent).

confidenceRubric.explicit: Additional Insured for ongoing operations required
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: CG 20 10 or equivalent required

canonicalWording: Per-project aggregate on GL
definition: General Aggregate limit must apply separately to this project rather than shared across all projects.
suggestedAction: Verify your policy has a per-project aggregate endorsement or can add one. Confirm with your agent before agreeing to this requirement.

confidenceRubric.explicit: General Aggregate applies per project
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Designated Construction Project General Aggregate endorsement required

canonicalWording: Flow-down to sub-subcontractors
definition: Requirements imposed on any subcontractors you hire - they must have same insurance/indemnity obligations.
suggestedAction: If you use sub-subcontractors, ensure they carry the same insurance and indemnity obligations. Obtain certificates from your subs that meet the contract requirements.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Subcontractor must bind lower tiers to same terms
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Flow down provisions to all sub-subcontractors

canonicalWording: Deductible/SIR declarations and limits
definition: Requirements to declare or limit deductibles/SIRs. OCIP deductibles can be very high and may vary by party.
suggestedAction: Disclose your deductibles as required. For OCIP projects, understand the deductible structure and how it applies to your scope before enrolling.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Maximum deductible/SIR specified or OCIP deductible structure
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Must disclose all deductibles

canonicalWording: 30-day cancellation notice requirement
definition: Requirement for 30-day notice of policy cancellation. Often difficult to obtain from carriers.
suggestedAction: Confirm with your agent whether your carrier can provide 30-day cancellation notice. This is often difficult to obtain—negotiate for 'endeavor to provide' language if possible.

confidenceRubric.explicit: 30 days written notice of cancellation required
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Advance notice required prior to cancellation

canonicalWording: Scheduled vs. blanket endorsements
definition: Requirement for scheduled (named) endorsements vs blanket coverage. Scheduled requires naming specific parties.
suggestedAction: Blanket endorsements are preferable as they automatically cover required parties. If scheduled endorsements are required, ensure all parties are correctly named on your policy.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Must provide scheduled endorsements naming specific parties
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Specific endorsement forms required

canonicalWording: Indemnity "to fullest extent permitted by law"
definition: Indemnity clause stretching to the legal limit. Often saves you from indemnifying for sole negligence in anti-indemnity states.
suggestedAction: This clause may actually protect you in anti-indemnity states by limiting indemnity to what's legally permitted. Consult your attorney to understand how state law affects this provision.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Indemnify to the fullest extent permitted by law
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Broad form indemnification

canonicalWording: OCIP excluding riggers liability coverage
definition: Many OCIPs do not include riggers liability coverage - they rely on your riggers liability. Understand that you may be providing this coverage even when enrolled in OCIP.
suggestedAction: Verify whether the OCIP includes riggers liability coverage. You may need to provide this coverage from your own policy even when enrolled in the OCIP.

confidenceRubric.explicit: OCIP specifically excludes riggers liability
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor responsible for own riggers liability under OCIP

canonicalWording: OCIP limit adequacy for project size
definition: OCIP limits may be inadequate for project size. $50M for 500+ condos shared with 100 subs may not be enough. You may have more coverage on your own policies.
suggestedAction: Compare OCIP limits to your own policies. Consider whether shared limits are adequate for the project size and number of enrolled parties.

confidenceRubric.explicit: OCIP limits appear insufficient for project scope
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Shared limits inadequate for number of parties

canonicalWording: High OCIP deductibles disproportionate to work
definition: OCIP deductibles can be very high ($100K+). For small projects ($10K of work), this creates disproportionate risk. Understand how deductibles are allocated.
suggestedAction: Understand the deductible amounts and structure before enrolling. Avoid OCIPs where the deductible is disproportionate to your project value/profit.

confidenceRubric.explicit: High OCIP deductible relative to contract value
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Deductible structure unfavorable for small scope

canonicalWording: OCIP eligibility not guaranteed for crane/rigging
definition: Crane/rigging excluded from OCIP approximately 1 in 3 times. Heavy haul almost always excluded (material transport only). Always verify eligibility with OCIP administrator before enrollment.
suggestedAction: Always verify eligibility with the OCIP administrator before enrollment. Crane/rigging is excluded ~1 in 3 times; heavy haul is almost always excluded.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Crane/Rigging specifically excluded from OCIP
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Eligibility subject to OCIP administrator approval

canonicalWording: Bidding with or net of insurance costs
definition: Requirement to exclude insurance costs from bid for OCIP. Understand how insurance rates factor into pricing and audit process.
suggestedAction: Understand how to calculate and deduct insurance costs from your bid. Work with your agent to determine accurate insurance rates for OCIP pricing.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Bid shall be net of insurance costs
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Deduct insurance premiums from price

canonicalWording: OCIP administrative burden (5-8 hours)
definition: OCIP enrollment causes 5-8 hours additional administration. Consider adding ~$500 to bid for OCIP administrative costs.
suggestedAction: Add approximately $500 to your bid to recoup administrative costs when participating in an OCIP.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Extensive OCIP reporting requirements
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Payroll reporting and enrollment burden

canonicalWording: Builders risk coverage and exclusions
definition: Terms regarding Builders Risk coverage. GCs may claim BR covers hoisted property, but BR often excludes contractor equipment (man lifts, etc.) that you may be rigging.
suggestedAction: Do not assume Builder's Risk covers property you are rigging. Verify BR policy exclusions—contractor equipment is often excluded. Clarify coverage responsibility before the lift.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Builders Risk policy details/exclusions specified
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Subcontractor responsible for BR deductible

canonicalWording: Cross suits / separation of insureds
definition: In OCIP, cross suits exclusion means enrolled parties cannot sue each other through the OCIP. If you are outside the OCIP, all enrolled parties can sue you.
suggestedAction: Understand cross-suits implications before declining OCIP enrollment. If you are outside the OCIP, all enrolled parties can pursue claims against you through the OCIP.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Cross suits exclusion or separation of insureds provision
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Parties enrolled cannot pursue claims against each other

canonicalWording: Bill of lading / cargo responsibility terms
definition: For heavy haul, understand bill of lading terms for when you are responsible for property during loading, unloading, or transport.
suggestedAction: Review and understand bill of lading terms for cargo responsibility during loading, unloading, and transport. Clarify when liability transfers.

confidenceRubric.explicit: Bill of lading terms allocating risk
confidenceRubric.strongParaphrase: Cargo responsibility during loading/unloading/transport
